threads.com:

Dawn of Black Friday deals edition

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

>Germany has sent Ukraine 14 of its state-of-the-art Panzerhaubitze (PzH) 2000 self-propelled howitzers, but problems emerged the moment they hit the battlefield. >Of these, only five will be heading back to the battlefield. Neither the German military nor its arms industry could provide the necessary spare parts to fix all the guns, the report continued, explaining that technicians had to cannibalize one of them to fix the others.

>The German government has been aware of this parts shortage since late summer, when the military warned it to order “extensive spare parts packages,” Der Spiegel claimed. Such an order was apparently not made, and the shortage has hampered Germany’s plans to set up a repair hub in Slovakia.

>In planning since September and announced by German Defense Minister Christine Lambrecht earlier this week, the repair hub will maintain howitzers and air-defense systems sent to Ukraine by Berlin.

>German military officials believe that Ukraine is firing as many as 300 rounds from each PzH 2000 per day, Friday’s report stated. Part of the appeal of using Nazi iconography in general is to express contempt for the post-war international order (and everything that goes along with it) and Dirlewanger happens to be the most extreme example of things the post-war international order (and everything that goes along with it) doesn't like about the Nazis.
In the east that usually tracks as anti-soviet and anti-russian, while in the west it tracks more towards antisemitism (specifically against Hollywood and the finance industry, usually). What the NSDAP in general and Dirlewanger in particular actually did is purely secondary.
As far as it being a joke, that's true, but the punchline is that it makes people I don't like upset. That was always the punchline for Nazi jokes (and it's usually still funny unless you absolutely botch the execution.)

>>56097623
Montana-class would have had 12 guns, but class was cancelled before they started building hulls. It was essentially stretched hull Iowa with extra main battery turret and slightly smaller set of boilers with design speed of 28kn instead of 33kn. Same secondary battery, same AA-batteries as Iowa initially had been planned to have, but in reality they added substantially more 40mm guns than they initially planned to have on Iowa. One would assume same would have happened to Montana and that had bit more superstructure real estate for even more 40mm mounts. Displacement would have risen from Iowas 48k standard and 58k full load to 62k standard and 70k full load on Montana-class. Production was suspended in 1940 and completely cancelled in 1943 as they now knew better and wanted more carriers.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
A subsonic bullet would have even lower energy. You can’t make the bullet heavier either as it would encroach too much into the powder column.

I think they could have made the cartridge longer. This would render it unable to be chambered in 9mm guns, but I think if you’re trying to make a 9mm competitor, you ought to make its own guns for it and sell it as an entire system. Kinda like the 5.7 or 7.5FK. They could have taken the black magic used in the p365/hellcat that shrink the grip down to woman hands tier, and scaled it up slightly to allow for something like a 1.4” OAL, similar to the 7.5FK. Longer bullets = wider expanded hollow points. Or shorter bullets with more powder/velocity/energy. 30SC just seems really mediocre. All it gains over 9mm is capacity. But those gains could have still been kept with an added benefit of improved terminal effect. 30SC is a one trick pony. I still like it and would like a hellcat chambered in it, but it is underwhelming as a new cartridge. Particularly underwhelming considered how it was marketed. Federal actually had the balls to claim it’s the biggest revolution in self-defense history.

I want to see how it performs with THV type bullets though and some fancy bullet construction, maybe with a hollow base, that keeps the bullet aligned in direction of travel while traversing tissue. I know THV-type bullets theoretically have excellent wounding capabilities, but they start to tumble almost immediately so the extra wounding effect is only present in the first few inches of penetration

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
What do you think is "sufficient/adequate" amount of magazine capacity for semi-auto pistols?
To specify, let's divide this into three broad categories.

1) Pocket pistols / EDC / self-defense
These are the small ones you carry with you in case shit hits the fan and you need to "cap some ass" as the youth puts it. We all know that in 94% of such cases, the situation ends with 4 or less shots. And 99% end without any need to reload the gun. A revolver with six shots should be perfectly adequate for self-defense. So 6+1 semi-auto should be enough for pocket pistol, yes?

2) Service weapons. For Police, military, security forces use. These are the full-sized guns that you openly carry as part of your uniform.
I think that the standard load-out for these is something like 15-18 rounds in a gun + two space mags on the belt, yes? A Beretta M9 seems to do just fine with only 15 rounds, and is kinda-sorta seen as acceptable choice. CZ75 (which has been used as service weapon for like 30 major countries + numerous clones) holds 16. Glock 17 holds 17, and is pretty much considered the modern standard, if for nothing else than easy procurement and availability of spare parts.

3) Competition/sports/hobby guns. These are the fancy ones. With all the bells and whistles with red-dots and attached flashlights and hair triggers and whatnot. These usually have a slightly higher mag capacity than the service models, anything between 18-20 or so. They also seem to be often hammer-fired and have a dedicated safety switch. Usually for match rules.

So in this thread I would just like to ask, what do you consider to be "suitable" amount of ammo for specific uses? Don't just say "as much as possible" because that's the easy way out.

So? is 6+1 enough for a pocket pistol? Is 15 enough for a service weapon or do you REALLY need that extra 2-3 rounds? Are competition level guns overkill outside matches?

Pictured: Buffalo Soldier.

https://www.policeone.com/officer-shootings/articles/117909-Study-reveals-important-truths-hidden-in-the-details-of-officer-involved-shootings/

Then consider that most police officers don't practice outside of their extremely easy mandatory biyearly 50 round qualifications where they might shoot another 50 rounds to warm up for a total of 200 rounds per year, and are prone to panic firing in situations where more than one officer is present, on top of being expected to chase fleeing criminals which will put them into crazier situations than you might be in and having body armor to make those situations more survivable. Then consider that when it comes to self defense shootings, you're more likely to be killed while defending yourself than you are to shoot more than 2 attackers because of how quickly scenarios that aren't full blown firefights with parties involved using cover play out (which you have basically no reason to get into). Situational awareness > having a gun on you > regular practice and having it on target first > having ammo that will penetrate far enough to take your attacker down with proper shot placement > having a reliable gun that holds more than one round and preferably fires as fast as you can pull the trigger >>>>>>>> basically everything else.

>Are competition level guns overkill outside matches
Yes. The modifications that they do are designed around shaving fractions of a second off your time to complete absolute shooting galleries of stages that don't remotely reflect what can actually happen in real life to beat competitors with comparable skill.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56095073
I’d just stick at the 25, 50 and 100 personally. If you’re not on paper at 25 with a bore sight you have bigger issues. Use groupings rather than individual shots, make sure you have a specific point of aim, steady firing position, no flinch, all that jazz. Then it’s as simple as working out how many clicks you need to move. So at 25 yards, 1 click is 1/2 an inch, 50 is 1 inch, 100 is 2 inches. Start at 25 first. It’s just personal preference what range you zero to, but I’d just stick with 50. Just keep in mind that you won’t get a more accurate zero than your scopes MOA.
